Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with severe, life-threatening symptoms of an unknown illness.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the unfinished code sample taunting me. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind: “I expect you to have this ready before our next meeting.” I wanted to prove myself, to show I was reliable and capable. But just as I started typing, my pager shrilled. The ER needed me—stat. A patient had arrived, gasping for breath, skin mottled, eyes wild with fear. The nurses looked to me for answers. I felt the weight of their expectation: I was the doctor, the one who had to make sense of chaos, to diagnose and save a life. My mind raced through possible causes, but I couldn’t shake the thought of the code sample waiting for me, the disappointment I’d see in my mentor’s eyes if I failed. I felt split in two, torn between the promise I’d made as a mentee and the oath I’d sworn as a doctor. My hands trembled as I reached for the patient’s chart, my mind wrestling with the impossible choice before me.
